conversation.content: I need to ask you something about the storage unit in the basement, the one you said was for your tools. [pause] There's copper piping in there with construction site tags still attached.
[defensive] Those are leftovers from legitimate jobs, material that would've been thrown out anyway. The foreman knows I take scrap sometimes.
[quietly firm] Scrap doesn't come wrapped in manufacturer's plastic with next week's delivery dates printed on the labels, Marcus.
[bristling] You went through my stuff? That's a locked unit, you had no right to go snooping around down there!
The landlord asked me to check for a water leak, gave me the master key. [exhales] I wasn't snooping, but now I wish I hadn't seen any of it.
Look, you don't understand how this industry works, okay? Everyone takes a little here and there, it's factored into the budgets.
[incredulous] Factored in?
[rapidly] My cousin's site manager, he's the one who suggested it. Said I could make an extra two grand a month if I was smart about it.
[hollow] Two grand a month. Jesus, Marcus, that's not skimming, that's organized theft. How long has this been going on?
[quieter] Six months, maybe seven. Started small with just some rebar and wire, but then the opportunity kept presenting itself and I had bills to pay.
If anyone traces this back here, we both lose this apartment. My name's on the lease too, you realize that, right?
[desperately] Nobody's going to trace anything! I've been careful, I rotate sites, never take from the same project twice in a row. [sighs] This is how I'm keeping my head above water.
[wistful] Remember when you moved in, you talked about saving up to start your own contracting business, doing things the right way?
Yeah, well, that dream died when my dad's medical bills hit forty thousand. [bitter laugh] The right way doesn't pay for chemo treatments.
You never told me.
[defeated whisper] What was I supposed to say? That I'm stealing from job sites to keep my father alive? That every beam I pocket might buy him another month?
[slowly] I want it all gone by tomorrow night, every piece, and then we need to figure out how to help your dad without you ending up in prison.
[shakily] You're not calling the cops? Even after seeing all that down there, knowing what I've been doing under your roof?
[exhausted] No, I'm not calling anyone. But this stops now, Marcus. We'll find another way, even if it means I help with the medical bills myself.
[breaking] I can't ask you to do that. You barely know my family, and this mess I've created, it's mine to clean up. [long exhale]
